rev.diff:
Line 3: Line 3:
''GNU/Linux'' is the term promoted by the [[Free Software Foundation]] (FSF), its founder [[Richard Stallman]], and its supporters, for operating systems that include [[GNU]] software and the [[Linux kernel]].<ref name="linuxandgnu">[http://www.gnu.org/gnu/linux-and-gnu.html GNU project website]</ref> The FSF argues for the term ''GNU/Linux'' because GNU was a longstanding project to develop a free operating system, of which the kernel was the last missing piece.<ref name="linuxandgnu"/> Proponents of the ''Linux'' term dispute ''GNU/Linux'' for a number of reasons.
''GNU/Linux'' is the term promoted by the [[Free Software Foundation]] (FSF), its founder [[Richard Stallman]], and its supporters, for operating systems that include [[GNU]] software and the [[Linux kernel]].<ref name="linuxandgnu">[http://www.gnu.org/gnu/linux-and-gnu.html GNU project website]</ref> The FSF argues for the term ''GNU/Linux'' because GNU was a longstanding project to develop a free operating system, of which the kernel was the last missing piece.<ref name="linuxandgnu"/> Proponents of the ''Linux'' term dispute ''GNU/Linux'' for a number of reasons.
â
Among the "top ten distributions" listed at [[DistroWatch]], two ([[Debian GNU/Linux]] and [[Knoppix|Knoppix live GNU/Linux system]]) use the term ''GNU/Linux'' in their official names, three ([[Ubuntu (Linux distribution)|Ubuntu]], [[openSUSE]], [[Fedora (Linux distribution)|Fedora]]) use neither ''Linux'' nor ''GNU/Linux'' in their names, four ([[Mandriva Linux]], [[MEPIS|Mepis Linux]], [[Slackware Linux]], and [[Gentoo Linux]]) use ''Linux'' in their names, and one ([[PCLinuxOS]]) uses a derivative name.<ref>[http://distrowatch.com/dwres.php?resource=major Top Ten Distributions] on DistroWatch.com</ref>
+
Among the "top ten distributions" listed at [[DistroWatch]], two ([[Debian GNU/Linux]] and [[Knoppix|Knoppix live GNU/Linux system]]) use the term ''GNU/Linux'' in their official names, three ([[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]], [[openSUSE]], [[Fedora (Linux distribution)|Fedora]]) use neither ''Linux'' nor ''GNU/Linux'' in their names, four ([[Mandriva Linux]], [[MEPIS|Mepis Linux]], [[Slackware Linux]], and [[Gentoo Linux]]) use ''Linux'' in their names, and one ([[PCLinuxOS]]) uses a derivative name.<ref>[http://distrowatch.com/dwres.php?resource=major Top Ten Distributions] on DistroWatch.com</ref>
